level.text: 1599.1 When used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall havehe meanings ascribed:
Act – The District of Columbia Wastewater System Regulation Act of 1985D.C. Law 6-95; D.C. Official Code §§ 8-105.01, et seq. (2008 Repl. &011 Supp)), as amended.

Analytical Testing – all methods of sample collection, preservation, andnalysis as prescribed in 40 C.F.R. § 136, “Guidelines Establishing Testsrocedures for the Analysis of Pollutants under the Clean Water Act.”

Best Management Practices (BMPs) – schedules of activities, prohibitionsf practices, maintenance procedures, and other management practices tomplement the prohibitions listed in 40 C.F.R. § 403.5(a)(1) and (b), and localretreatment requirements. BMPs also include treatment requirements, operatingrocedures, and practices to control plant site runoff, spillage or leaks,ludge or waste disposal, or drainage from raw materials storage.

Biochemical Oxygen Demand (BOD) – oxygen utilized in the biochemicalxidation of organic matter in five (5) days at twenty degrees Centigrade20oC), expressed in milligrams per liter (mg/l) as determined by the methods ofnalytical Testing.

Biosolids – wastewater sludge and residue that has been processed through wastewater treatment system to meet the pathogen reduction and vectorttraction reduction requirements of 40 C.F.R. § 503.15 for land application asertilizer and soil amendment.
Blue Plains – The District of Columbia’s Wastewater Treatment Plantt Blue Plains, a POTW.

Categorical Pretreatment Standards or Categorical Standards or Nationalategorical Pretreatment Standards – any regulation promulgated by thenvironmental Protection Agency (EPA) in accordance with Sections 307(b) and (c)f the Clean Water Act which specifies quantities or concentrations ofollutants or pollutant properties which may be discharged to a POTW by existingr new Industrial Users in specific industrial categories provided in 40 C.F.R.hapter I, Subchapter N, Parts 405-471.
Categorical Wastewater – wastewater subject to National Categoricalretreatment Standards.

Chemical Oxygen Demand (COD) – the oxygen equivalent of that portion ofhe organic matter that is susceptible to oxidation by a strong chemicalxidant. The values shall be as determined by the methods of Analytical Testing.
Clean Water Act – the Federal Water Pollution Control Act approved October8, 1972 (86 Stat. 816; 33 U.S.C. §§ 1251, et seq).
C.F.R. – the Code of Federal Regulations.
Combined Sewer – a sewer which is intended by the District to serve asoth a storm sewer and sanitary sewer.

Compatible Pollutants – biochemical oxygen demand, total suspended solids,H, and fecal coliform bacteria, plus additional pollutants identified by WASAf the wastewater treatment plant in fact removes such additional pollutants to substantial degree. The term “substantial degree” is not subjecto precise definition, but generally contemplates removals in the order ofighty percent (80%) or greater. Minor incidentals removals in the order of teno thirty percent (10% to 30%) are not considered substantial. Examples of thedditional pollutants which may be considered compatible include the following:
Chemical oxygen demand;
Total organic carbon;
Phosphorous and phosphorous compounds; and
Nitrogen and nitrogen compounds.

Contributing Jurisdiction – a jurisdiction whose Industrial Users are locatedutside the jurisdictional boundary of a User Jurisdiction, but the dischargesrom the Industrial Users discharge into the User Jurisdiction sewer system andltimately into WASA’s wastewater system.
Cooling Water – the wastewaters discharged from any system of heatransfer, such as condensation, air conditioning, cooling or refrigeration tohich the only pollutant added is heat.
Daily Maximum – the arithmetic average of all effluent samples for a pollutantollected during a calendar day.

Daily Maximum Limit – the maximum allowable discharge limit of a pollutanturing a calendar day. Where Daily Maximum Limits are expressed in units ofass, the daily discharge is the total mass discharged over the course of theay. Where Daily Maximum Limits are expressed in terms of a concentration, theaily discharge is the arithmetic average measurement of the pollutantoncentration derived from all measurements taken that day.
DCMR – the District of Columbia Municipal Regulations.
Discharge – any solid, liquid, or gas introduced into the wastewaterystem, including indirect discharges.
District – the District of Columbia, a municipal corporation.
District Pretreatment Standards or Local Limits – those limits found in 21CMR § 1501 and D.C. Official Code § 8-105.06 (2008 Repl. & 2011 Supp.)).

Domestic Wastewater – Any wastewater produced by ordinary living uses,ncluding, but not limited to, liquid waste containing animal or vegetableatter in suspension or solution, or the water-carried waste from the dischargef water closets, laundry tubs, washing machines, sinks, dishwashers, or otherources of water-carried wastes of human origin. This definition includesastewater from commercial, industrial or residential sources which is of aimilar quality, constituents and strength, to that produced by these samerdinary living uses.
EPA – the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.

Garbage – solid wastes from domestic and commercial preparation, cooking,r dispensing of food, or from the handling, storage, or sale of produce. Forurposes of this chapter, “garbage” is not the same as#8220;shredded garbage”.

Grease Abatement System – Any grease interceptor, grease trap, greaseecovery device, or any treatment system designed to remove Fats, Oils andrease (FOG) from food service establishments, including but not limited to,afeterias, hotel kitchens, church kitchens, school kitchens, hospitalafeterias, bars, or any other commercial food service establishment.

Hazardous Waste – waste defined as hazardous waste in the District ofolumbia Hazardous Waste Management Act of 1977, effective March 16, 1978 (D.C.aw 2-64; D.C. Official Code § 8-1302(2) (2008 Repl. & 2011 Supp.)), asmended.

Health Care Facility – a facility defined as a health care facility in thenused Pharmaceutical Safe Disposal Act of 2009, effective March 5, 2010 (D.C.aw 18-112; D.C. Official Code § 48-851.01 (2009 Repl. & 2011 Supp.)), asmended.
High Strength Wastewater – wastewater containing concentrations of organicatter, solids, or nutrients that are higher than domestic strength wastewaters established by WASA.
Incompatible Pollutant – any pollutant which is not a “compatibleollutant” as defined in this section.

Indirect Discharge – the introduction of pollutants into a POTW or theistrict’s wastewater system from any non-domestic source regulated underection 307(b), (c), or (d) of the Clean Water Act and the Act.
Industrial User or IU – a source of Indirect Discharge from a non-domesticser who discharges, causes, or permits the discharge of wastewater into theistrict’s wastewater system.

Infectious Waste – any waste defined as infectious waste in the Solidaste Facility Permit Act of 1995, effective February 27, 1996 (D.C. Law 11-94;.C. Official Code § 8-1051(21) (2008 Repl. & 2011 Supp.)), as amended.

Institutional pharmacy – a pharmacy defined as an institutional pharmacy inhe Unused Pharmaceutical Safe Disposal Act of 2009, effective March 5, 2010D.C. Law 18-112; D.C. Official Code § 48-851.01 (2009 Repl. & 2011upp.)), as amended.
Interference – a discharge which, alone or in conjunction with a discharger discharges from other sources, both:
Inhibits or disrupts the District’s wastewater system, its treatmentrocesses or operations, or its sludge processes, use or disposal; and

Therefore is a cause of a violation of any requirement of WASA’s Nationalollutant Discharge Elimination System permit (including an increase in theagnitude or duration of a violation) or of the prevention of sewage sludge user disposal in compliance with the following statutory provisions andegulations or permits issued thereunder (or more stringent State or localegulations):
Section 405 of the Clean Water Act;

Solid Waste Disposal Act (SWDA) including Title II, more commonly referredo as the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) and including State oristrict regulations contained in any State or District sludge management planrepared pursuant to subtitle D of the SWDA;
Clean Air Act;
Toxic Substances Control Act; and
Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act.

International Standards Organization or ISO – An internationalon-governmental organization that develops international standards, such as ISO1143: Dentistry – Amalgam Separators, available through the ISO websitet http://www.iso.org.
Mayor – the Mayor of the District of Columbia or any representative orgency designated by the Mayor to carry out the provisions of the Act and theseegulations.

Medical Waste – any waste defined as medical waste in section 2(3A) of thellegal Dumping Enforcement Act of 1994, effective May 20, 1994 (D.C. Law0-117; D.C. Official Code § 8-901(3A) (2008 Repl.)), as amended.

National Pretreatment Standards, Pretreatment Standards, or Standards –ny regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by the EPA inccordance with section 307(b) and (c) of the Clean Water Act, which applies tondustrial Users. National Pretreatment Standards, Pretreatment Standards, ortandards includes prohibitive discharge limits established pursuant to 40.F.R. § 403.5, D.C. Official Code § 8-105.06 (2008 Repl. & 2011 Supp.),nd this chapter.
Natural Outlet – any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, river, lake,r other body of surface water.
New Source -

Any building, structure, facility or installation from which there is oray be a discharge of pollutants, the construction of which commenced after theublication of proposed pretreatment standards under section 307(c) of the Cleanater Act, which will be applicable to such source if such standards arehereafter promulgated in accordance with that section, provided that:
The building, structure, facility or installation is constructed at a sitet which no other source is located;
The building, structure, facility, or installation totally replaces therocess or production equipment that causes the discharge of pollutants at anxisting source; or

The production or wastewater generating processes of the building, facilityr installation are substantially independent of an existing source at the sameite. In determining whether these are substantially independent, factors suchs the extent to which the new facility is integrated with the existing plant,nd the extent to which the new facility is engaged in the same general type ofctivity as the existing source should be considered;

Construction on a site at which an existing source is located results in aodification rather than a new source if the construction does not create a newuilding, structure, facility or installation meeting the criteria of paragraphsa)(2) and (a)(3) above, but otherwise alters, replaces, or adds to existingrocess or production equipment; and
Construction of a new source as defined above has commenced if the owner orperator has:
Begun or caused to begin as part of a continuous onsite constructionrogram:
Any placement, assembly, or installation of facilities or equipment; or

Significant site preparation work including clearing, excavation, or removalf existing buildings, structures, or facilities which is necessary for thelacement, assembly, or installation of new source facilities or equipment; or

Entered into a binding contractual obligation for the purchase of facilitiesr equipment which are intended to be used in its operation within a reasonableime. Options to purchase or contracts which can be terminated or modifiedithout substantial loss, and contracts for feasibility, engineering, and designtudies do not constitute a contractual obligation under this paragraph.
Non-Contact Cooling Water – water used for cooling which does not come intoirect contact with any raw material, product, byproduct, or waste.

Non-Significant Categorical Industrial User – an Industrial User subject toategorical Pretreatment Standards under 40 C.F.R. § 403.6 and 40 C.F.R.hapter I, Subchapter N that WASA determines is a Non-Significant Categoricalndustrial User rather than a Significant Categorical Industrial User on ainding that the Industrial User does not discharge more than one-hundredallons per day (100 gal./day) of total categorical wastewater (excludinganitary, non-contact cooling and boiler blowdown wastewater, unlesspecifically included in the pretreatment standard) and the following conditionsre met:
The Industrial User, prior to WASA’s finding has consistently compliedith all applicable Categorical Pretreatment Standards and requirements;
The Industrial User annually submits the certification statement required in 1508.9 together with any additional information necessary to support theertification statement; and
The Industrial User never discharges any untreated concentrated wastewater.

Non-Significant Non-Categorical Industrial User – an Industrial User that isot subject to Categorical Pretreatment Standards, discharges less thanwenty-five gallons per day (25,000 gal./day) of process wastewater, andpecifically designated by WASA due to type of business, characteristics of theischarge, or presence of pretreatment facilities.

Non-wastewater flows – discharges that do not result from an industrialrocess, which include storm waters (including snow melt), surface waters,round waters, subsurface drainage (including foundation, footing, and underrainage), cooling waters, roof drainage, irrigation waters, diverted streamlows, and spring waters.

North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) – the classification andlassification numbers of Users based on the 2007 North American Industrylassification Manual by the Executive Office of the President, Office ofanagement and Budget, as it may be revised, updated, replaced, or amended.

NPDES Permit – means the National Pollution Discharge Elimination Systemermit issued by the EPA Region III to WASA for the operation of the Blue Plainsastewater Treatment Facility in effect on September 30, 2010, and as it may bemended or modified in the future, and any successor permits issued by the EPAegion III to either the District or to WASA.
Nuisance – any condition, state or combination of circumstances whichnjures, or threatens or endangers health, safety, or welfare.
Objectionable Color – a color inappropriate for the normal characteristicsf the receiving water.

Pass Through – any discharge which exits the District’s Wastewaterystem into waters of the United States in quantities or concentrations which,lone or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources,auses or may cause, or contributes to, a violation of any requirement of thePDES permit including an increase in the magnitude or duration of a violation.

Person – any natural person, partnership, co-partnership, firm, company,orporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, governmentalntity or any other legal entity, or their legal representatives, agents, orssigns.
pH – the logarithm to the base ten (10) of the reciprocal of theoncentration of hydrogen ion in grams per liter (g/l) of solution as determinedy the methods of Analytical Testing.
Pharmaceutical Product – a drug or biologic regulated by the federal Foodnd Drug Administration.
Pharmaceutical Waste – a pharmaceutical product, which is no longer suitableor its intended purpose or is otherwise being discarded.
Phosphorus or Total Phosphorus (TP) – phosphorus content in wastewater asetermined by the methods of Analytical Testing.

Pollutant – any substance which induces or may induce an alteration of thehemical, physical, biological, or radiological integrity of water, which has oray have a detrimental effect on a subsequent use of that water, or whichnterferes or may interfere with the District’s wastewater system.

Pretreatment- the reduction of the amount of pollutants, the elimination ofollutants, or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties inastewater prior to or in lieu of discharging or otherwise introducing suchollutants to the District’s wastewater system. This reduction or alterationay be obtained by physical, chemical, or biological processes, process changes,r by other means, except as prohibited by 40 C.F.R. § 403.6(d) and section(h) of the Act. Appropriate pretreatment technology includes control equipment,uch as equalization tanks or facilities, for protection against surges or slugoadings that might interfere with or otherwise be incompatible with theistrict’s wastewater system. However, if wastewater from a regulated processs mixed in an equalization facility with unregulated wastewater or withastewater from another regulated process, the effluent from the equalizationacility must meet an adjusted pretreatment limit calculated in accordance with0 C.F.R. § 403.6(e).

Pretreatment Requirements – any District pretreatment standard or federal,tate, or local substantive or procedural requirement related to pretreatment,ther than a National Pretreatment Standard, imposed on an Industrial User.

Process Wastewater – wastewater discharged from an industrial process orontaminated non-wastewater flows that contain pollutant levels that exceed theistrict’s Pretreatment Standards (prior to treatment), excluding sanitary,oncontact cooling and boiler blowdown wastewater.

Publicly Owned Treatment Works or POTW – a treatment works as defined byection 212 of the Clean Water Act (33 U.S.C. § 1292), which is owned by atate or municipality, such as the District of Columbia. This definitionncludes any devices and systems used in the storage, treatment, recycling, andeclamation of municipal sewage or industrial wastes of a liquid nature. It alsoncludes sewers, pipes, and other conveyance, which convey wastewater to areatment plant.
Residue – the accumulated solids, grease, liquids, and scum separated fromastewater during the wastewater treatment process. Also referred to as#8220;sludge and residue”.
Responsible Corporate Officer – shall be:

A president, secretary, treasurer, or vice-president of the corporation inharge of a principal business function, or any other person who performsimilar policy- or decision-making functions for the corporation; or

The manager of one (1) or more manufacturing, production, or operatingacilities, provided, the manager is authorized to make management decisionshich govern the operation of the regulated facility including having thexplicit or implicit duty of making major capital investment recommendations,nd initiate and direct other comprehensive measures to assure long-termnvironmental compliance with environmental laws and regulations; can ensurehat the necessary systems are established or actions taken to gather completend accurate information for control mechanism requirements; and where authorityo sign documents has been assigned or delegated to the manager in accordanceith corporate procedures.
Sanitary Sewer Service Charge – the charge levied against Users to recoverhe costs of rendering wastewater treatment system services.

Septic Tank – a watertight receptacle which receives the discharge from arainage system or a part of the drainage system, and is designed andonstructed to separate solids from the liquid, decompose organic matter through period of detention, and allow the liquids to discharge into the soil outsidef the tank.
Sewer – any pipe or conduit for conveying wastewater or drainage water.

Shredded Garbage – garbage that has been shredded to such a degree thatll particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normallyrevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one inch (1 in.) inimension. For purposes of this chapter, “shredded garbage” is nothe same as “garbage”.

Significant Accidental Discharge – any unintentional or uncontrolledelease of pollutant(s) which results in a violation of a permit issued pursuanto this chapter or results in a violation of the NPDES permit issued to operatelue Plains.

Significant Categorical Industrial User – an Industrial User that is subjecto Categorical Pretreatment Standards under 40 C.F.R. § 403.6 and 40 C.F.R.hapter I, subchapter N and does not meet the requirements as a Non-Significantategorical Industrial User.
Significant Industrial User -
Except as provided in paragraph (b) below, any Industrial User that either:
Is an Industrial User subject to Categorical Pretreatment Standards under0 C.F.R. § 403.6 and 40 C.F.R. chapter I, subchapter N; and
Any other Industrial User that:

Discharges an average of twenty-five thousand gallons per day (25,000al./day) or more of process wastewater to the District’s wastewater system orther POTW (excluding sanitary, noncontact cooling and boiler blowdownastewater);
Contributes a process wastestream which makes up five percent (5%) or moref the average dry weather hydraulic or organic capacity of Blue Plains; or

Is designated as a Significant Industrial User by WASA on the basis that thendustrial User has a reasonable potential for adversely affecting the operationf Blue Plains or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement, forarming the environment or for causing a threat to wastewater utility personnel.

Upon a finding that an Industrial User meeting the criteria in (a)(2)(A)-(C)as no reasonable potential for adversely affecting the operation of Blue Plainsr for violating any pretreatment standards or requirements, WASA may at anyime, on its own initiative or in response to a petition received from anndustrial User, and in accordance with 40 C.F.R. § 403.8(f)(6), determine thatuch Industrial User is not a Significant Industrial User.

Significant Noncompliance – for the purposes of this chapter, aignificant Industrial User is in significant noncompliance with theretreatment standards and requirements if it violates a term of a dischargeermit and it’s violation meets one (1) or more of the criteria listed in §515, or an Industrial User whose violation meets one (1) or more of theriteria listed in § 1515.3(c), (d), or (h) of this chapter.

Significantly Changed Operation – WASA shall determine what constitutes a”significantly changed operation” on a case-by-case basis byeference to such factors as the increase in the level of pollutant(s)ischarged, the potential for the discharge of additional pollutants or theotential for accidental or uncontrolled discharges as a result of processodifications, production increases, equipment modifications and the like.

Slug Discharge or Slug Load – any discharge of a non-routine, episodicature, including but not limited to, an accidental spill or a non-customaryatch discharge, which has a reasonable potential to cause interference or passhrough, or in any other way violate WASA’s regulations, local limits, orermit conditions such that it is capable of violating the specific prohibitedischarge limits and local pretreatment requirements in § 1501 of this chapter.

Standard Industrial Classification – the classification and classificationumbers of Users based on the 1987 Standard Industrial Classification ManualSIC) by the Executive Office of the President, Office of Management and Budget,s it may be revised, updated, replaced or amended.
Termination of Service – includes closing off or removing branch sewer(s),isconnecting water service(s) and removal of water service lines.

Total Kjeldahl Nitrogen (TKN) – the sum of the content of organic nitrogen,mmonia and ammonium in the wastewater, expressed in milligrams per liter (mg/l)s determined by the methods of Analytical Testing.

Total Suspended Solids (TSS) – solids that either float on the surface of,r may be suspended in, water, sewage, or other liquids, and which may beemovable by laboratory filtering, with concentrations expressed in milligramser liter (mg/l). The value shall be as determined by the methods of Analyticalesting.
Toxic Pollutant – any pollutant which is identified as toxic by the EPA orhich is designated as toxic by WASA.
Uncontaminated Non-Wastewater Flows – non-wastewater flows that containollutants at levels that do not exceed the District’s pretreatment standards.
User – any person who discharges, causes, or permits the discharge ofastewater into the District’s wastewater system.

User Jurisdictions – the jurisdiction that directly or indirectly connects tor discharges into, the District’s wastewater system, including Montgomeryounty and Prince George’s County, Maryland, as represented by theashington Suburban Sanitary Commission; Fairfax County, Virginia; Loudounounty, Virginia; and Vienna, Virginia.
WASA – the District of Columbia Water and Sewer Authority.

Waste – sewage and any and all other waste substances of human or animalrigin, or associated with human habitation, or resulting from any production,torage, manufacturing or processing operation of whatever nature, whetheriquid, solid, gaseous or radioactive. This definition includes such wasteslaced within containers of whatever nature prior to, and for purposes of,isposal.
Wastewater – means the liquid and water-carried wastes from dwellings,ommercial buildings, industrial facilities, institutions, and swimming pools.

Wastewater System – means the devices, facilities, structures, equipment,r works owned, operated, maintained, or used by the District or WASA for theurpose of the transmission, storage, treatment, recycling, and reclamation ofastewater or to recycle or reuse water, including intercepting sewers, outfallewers, wastewater collection systems, treatment, pumping, power, and otherquipment and their appurtenances, extensions, improvements, remodeling ofmprovements, additions, and alterations to the additions, elements essential torovide a reliable recycled water supply such as standby treatment units andlear well facilities, and any works, including land, that are or may be anntegral part of the treatment process or that are or may be used for disposalf sludge and residue resulting from such treatment, and sewers designated astorm sewers shall be considered a part of the wastewater system for purposes ofhis subchapter.
